citation.article-title: Ruminococcus palustris sp. nov. - a psychroactive anaerobic organism from a swamp.

p.s: Description of Ruminococcus palustris sp. nov.
Ruminococcus palustris (pa.lu'stris adj. L. - palustris, swamp-inhabiting ruminococcus)
Cells are coccoid or somewhat elongated, with slightly tapered ends, especially after division.
The cell size is 0.75 - 1.3 x 0.7 - 1 μm.
Cells occur singly or in pairs and short chains joined by a mucous capsule.
Reproduction occurs by binary fission with septa formation.
Cells are Gram-positive; spores are not formed.
Growth occurs within a temperature range of 0-33° C, with an optimum at 30°C.
A high growth rate is observed at 6°C.
The pH range within which growth is possible is 6.2 - 8.4, with an optimum at 7.5.

The organism is anaerobic and chemoorganotrophic; it ferments glucose, sucrose, fructose, mannose, maltose, raffinose, lactose, cellobiose, mannitol, sorbitol, pyruvate, and N,N-acetyl-D-glucosamine, but not pentoses; polysaccharides are not hydrolyzed.
The products of glucose fermentation are lactate, acetate, ethanol, formate, and traces of isobutyrate.

The peculiarities of the cell envelope lipid composition are as follows: the main components of the lipid complex are monounsaturated fatty acids C16:1 and C18:1; a distinctive feature is the presence of monounsaturated fatty acids C14:1 with the double bond at carbon atom 9 or 11.
The DNA GC content (determined from the melting point) is 47.5 mol %.
The habitats are valley swamps of the temperate zone.
The type strain is Z-7189 (= DSM 9172).
